title: This sweet plant compound could protect your teeth by blocking bacteria
description: Scientists believe a surprising plant extract could be harnessed in dental products.
content:
Scientists may have identified a sweet solution to tooth decay in the form of a natural compound that can combat bacteria. While studying food borne pathogens, they noticed that listeria appeared to easily form layers of bacteria on most wood — but avoided maple. The researchers isolated compounds called polyphenols from the plant and tested them against a type of bacteria, Streptococcus mutans. Study author Dr Mark Gomelsky, an expert in microbiology at the University of Wyoming in the US, said: “Since S.mutans initiates cavities by forming biofilms (plaques) on teeth and producing acid that destroys tooth enamel, we asked: could maple polyphenols also inhibit S.mutans biofilms?”

Lab tests showed that maple polyphenols were able to block the bacteria from forming biofilms on plastic teeth. Dr Gomelsky added: “Everything fell into place just as we predicted. That’s a rare experience in science, and probably the first time it’s happened in my 35-year research career. “We discovered that several polyphenols present in maple wood or maple sap can inhibit the sortase enzyme in S. mutans, which in turn prevents this cavity-causing bacterium from attaching to tooth surfaces.” They also prevented bacteria growth on a material that mimics tooth enamel. The team now hopes the maple compounds could be used in dental products to prevent cavities.

Such products could be safer than those which rely on killing bacteria, including mouthwash, which can be dangerous if swallowed by young children, they said. Almost a quarter of five-year-olds in England had “visually obvious tooth decay” in the 2021-2022 school year, official figures show. The findings were published in Microbiology Spectrum, a journal of the American Society for Microbiology.

summary: Scientists from the University of Wyoming have discovered that maple polyphenols, a natural compound that can combat bacteria, could potentially prevent tooth decay. The researchers isolated these compounds from the plant and tested them against Streptococcus mutans, a type of bacteria that causes cavities. The study author Dr Mark Gomelsky described this as a rare occurrence in science, and the team hopes these compounds could be used in dental products that could be safer than traditional ones that use killing bacteria. The findings were published in Microbiology Spectrum, a journal of the American Society for Microbiology.
shortSummary: Scientists may have discovered a natural compound, maple polyphenols, that blocks bacteria from forming biofilms on teeth, potentially being used in dental products.

argos_summary: Researchers have discovered that polyphenols extracted from maple wood can inhibit the growth of Streptococcus mutans, the bacteria responsible for tooth decay. In laboratory tests, these compounds effectively blocked the bacteria from forming biofilms on surfaces mimicking tooth enamel. The findings suggest that maple polyphenols could be used in dental products as a safer alternative to traditional antibacterial mouthwashes, potentially helping to reduce the prevalence of cavities, especially among children.
